DOC.brief_summary: The primary objective determine whether High Flow Nasal Cannula ( HFNC ) superior respiratory modality neonates ≥36 week transient tachypnea newborn ( TTN ) compare standard care modality ( NCPAP ) .
DOC.brief_title: High Flow Nasal Cannula Versus Bubble Nasal CPAP Treatment Transient Tachypnea Newborn Infants ≥ 35 Weeks Gestation
DOC.detailed_description: Transient Tachypnea Newborn , fetal lung fluid retention cause poor lung compliance atelectasis , common entity neonate ≥ 36 week unit . Currently standard care include use respiratory modality bubble nasal continuous positive airway pressure ( BNCPAP ) support neonates illness . BNCPAP provide positive distending pressure recruit alveoli prevent atelectasis , however , associate air leak ( pneumothorax , pneumomediastinum ) , nasal irritation necrosis , intolerance . HFNC another respiratory modality use high flow gas also provide positive distend pressure thus prevent atelectasis . This modality cause nasal irritation necrosis minimal risk air leak . We postulate HFNC superior modality BNCPAP treat neonate ≥ 36 week TTN . This determine compare duration respiratory support ( hour ) newborns ≥ 36 week gestation diagnosis TTN randomize receive either NCPAP HFNC respiratory care .
DOC.criteria: gestational age ≥ 35 week diagnosis TTN , define respiratory rate > 60 , presence subcostal /or intercostal retraction , nasal flaring , grunting , oxygen saturation 7093 % room air , radiological evidence perihilar streak patchy infiltrates admission NICU Mount Sinai hospital within first 24 hour life gestational age < 35 week history thick meconium stain fluid and/or diagnosis meconium aspiration syndrome diagnosis major congenital pulmonary cardiac anomaly initial CXR demonstrate air leak respiratory distress first occur 24 hour life presumptive diagnosis RDS indicate need FiO2 > 40 % , severe retraction grunt poor air entry , diffuse alveolar consolidation chest radiograph
